paragraphs: It Starts With The Heart

When we refer to the heart, we generally think of it from a biological standpoint. As a vital organ, if the heart ever stops pumping blood to the rest of our body, we would cease to live. The ancients referred to the heart as the emotional core and motivator for action, as opposed to the mind. Not only did God create us with a heart, but as King Solomon wrote in Ecclesiastes 3:11, “He has also set eternity in the human heart”. Furthermore, the Apostle Paul viewed the heart as a home in Ephesians 3:17, “Christ may dwell in your heart through faith”. It is in Ezra 1 where we see God moving upon human hearts and this is my prayer for you as you begin this bible engagement series through the books of Ezra & Nehemiah.

In Ezra 1: 1 (cf. 2 Chronicles 36: 22), “The Lord moved the heart of Cyrus king of Persia to make a proclamation throughout his realm and also to put it in writing.” Here we see God at work in the heart of a foreign king. Our God is the God of the nations. He ministers to the hearts of different people in different ways. We observe a series of exiles in scripture. Assyria took over Israel, Babylon took over Judah, Babylon took over Assyria and Persia-Media took over Babylon. King Cyrus was of the Persia-Media empire. What was so special about him? Nothing! God simply selected him to liberate the people of God and allow them to return to Jerusalem. How was that possible? God got a hold of his heart. I would also add that God moved upon King Cyrus's heart in order to fulfill the word of the Lord spoken through Jeremiah. Though Jeremiah felt like an unsuccessful prophet, God fulfilled every word spoken through him.

In Ezra 1: 5, we read, “Then the family heads of Judah and Benjamin, and the priests and Levites—everyone whose heart God had moved—prepared to go up and build the house of the Lord in Jerusalem.” I find this to be a very encouraging scripture because it means that God can still move the hearts of families and God can still move the hearts of spiritual leaders like pastors. What could happen if God got a hold of the heart of every person at WPA? What could we do or rebuild for the Lord? God does not only move on a singular heart, but on collective hearts.

As you read this devotional, here's the main point: In order for God's purposes to move forward in partnership with people, hearts need to be moved! Does the Lord have your heart; not part of it; all of it? Does the Lord have our hearts? Not one or two hearts; but all of our hearts? I encourage you to let God move your heart(s) today, for if He has your heart, He will have your mind, He will have your hands and feet, He will have your everything.
Pastor Chris Padiath

paragraphs: The Battle is the Lord's!

After laying down the foundation and celebrating with the priests in rebuilding the temple of God in Jerusalem, the tribes of Judah and Benjamin continued their task to rebuild the temple of the Lord as prophesied by the prophet Jeremiah, however, they encountered  opposition from adversaries. The adversaries were Samaritans who lived in Jerusalem at the time. The adversaries first came in an attempt to help, however, when their offer was wisely rejected by the builders, they took extra measures to oppose the building of the temple of the God of Israel. They now opposed them using influence and politics.

The God we serve is a loving and merciful God. He is always willing to forgive us of our sins. If we keep on living in sin, expecting that His grace will continually cover over our iniquity, this could lead to a dangerous lifestyle of continuous backsliding. Jeremiah 8 describes a gory picture of the result of Israel's continuous backsliding into idolatry (Jer. 8:19). Backsliding, just like idolatry, leads into bondage and eventual destruction of the life and destiny of a child of God. God does not take pleasure in the life of those who set their hand on the plough of the gospel and turn away (Heb. 10:38-39).

Despite experiencing the awesome power and salvation of God in Egypt and during the wilderness journey, Israel disobeyed God's commands and successive generations continuously crave other foreign gods and worship these idols made with human hands. This prompted God to teach erring Israel some lifetime lessons through hardships, wars and exiles. They used influence by engaging in bribery, creating fear and discouragement to cause the people of Judah to not continue their work. This was done over some time, through the reign of King Cyrus and King Darius of Persia.

When King Artaxerxes of Persia was in rule, the adversaries intensified their efforts by now using politics. They wrote a letter to King Artaxerxes with false claims against the people of Judah and Benjamin.

This pattern of using different ways to oppose the plans of God over extended periods is aligned with how the enemy attacks us in our everyday lives. Our adversary, the devil, attacks our call to love God, obey His commandments, parent in a godly way, serve God, love others and more. The goal of the enemy is to hinder us from fulfilling our God-given destiny like the people who were trying to rebuild the temple. As we continue to read the book of Ezra, with God's plans, no resource or political power of the adversary can stop the plans of God.

So how can we stay consistent when the opposition is so big and prolonged? We need to rely on God as He will restore us. We need to be wise, discerning and bold to resist when the enemy comes in sheep's clothing. We must be persistent and have faith to hold onto the prophecies of God over us even during attacks from the enemy.

We put ourselves in a position to do this by being in fellowship with our fellow believers, listening to God's instructions as taught by our pastors and increasing our knowledge of God by reading His word.

Remember, just like the rebuilding of the temple project was ordained by God, so our lives have been ordained in God's plans and so the battle belongs to the Lord. We only need to trust Him and follow His lead.
We pray for you to be steadfast through any opposition of the enemy and read through this devotional series with the church so that we may grow in faith and knowledge of the Lord Jesus Christ.
Steven Uhoutu (Deacon)

paragraphs: After These Things

“After these things” begins this chapter.  Spanning several generations of Achaemenid Kings, three words that sum up a signed and sealed royal decree of Cyrus, ordering the construction of the House of God in Jerusalem. The Archimedean Kings had supplied it all and once completed, worship began.  Onto such a stage, in 458 BC, steps Ezra, a priest of God, with a lineage to Aaron, the chief priest in the time of Moses.  As we should do with our spiritual heritage, Ezra knew his priestly pedigree and valued it. Intergenerational blessing is a real thing. We can wonder at it and should, for the prayers of those who have gone before us into eternity, do continue in their effectiveness in our lifetime.

Under the authority of King Artaxerxes, leaving Babylon, Ezra and his entourage of temple ministers, travelled five months to reach Jerusalem. Though enjoying the protection of an earthly king and his power, Ezra rightly attributed the blessing on his life ultimately to the “gracious hand of God.” Friends, despite all that we may be “given” by the hands of power in this world, as Christians, we must recognize and believe that it is all from God. We need to acknowledge Him in “all our ways.

Ezra was a man of God of singular focus. His priorities were “study and observance”. He was devoted to the Word and the way of the Word. To have learned under his teaching was to hear the theology of the Word as well as the practical application of the Word.  As James, the Apostle encouraged us about the Word, “Do what it says.” Something remarkable will then follow.

Does “study and observance” produce something in our lives? The world tells us the contrary, that it is a waste of time, but our author tells us that a lifestyle in and about the Word, changes things. The beginning of verse ten says “For”. This tiny word links lifestyle to favour. It is therefore implicitly understood that a lifestyle of devotion to God is the reason for the presence of His favour on Ezra's life. This is a profound and powerful revelation to us that our devotion to God, His Word, and the teaching of it, is directly proportional to the favour of the Lord in our life. This is not about a works-based salvation, but rather about pursuing a Word-based life with the Living God. Walk close to God and the things of life change in context before our eyes. Though this favour does not preclude the common pains and tragedies that may occur in life, it does however, supply the grace that we need to see it through until our last breath and into His eternal presence.

Ezra 7, among many lessons, tells us to proceed, to continue and to persevere. The completion of the temple was not the end, but rather a new beginning. “Bless the Lord”, God is not finished with you or I.
Jeffrey Young (Elder)

paragraphs: Collective Accountability & Repentance

“Ezra prayed and confessed, weeping and falling face down before the house of God, an extremely large assembly of Israelite men, women, and children gathered around him. The people also wept bitterly.” (Ezra 10:1)

When we think of accountability, this is perhaps one of the last pictures that our minds paint for us. Many would think of accountability as sharing a deep hurt or sin with one trusted friend, small group leader, discipleship partner or pastor. The Israelites example of collective sin, brokenness, repentance and reconciliation before God provides an essential picture of a profoundly accountable community.

Collectively, this community sinned against God. Instead of keeping God's command “to separate themselves from the surrounding peoples with detestable practices” (Ezra 9:1-2), they willingly chose union with them in the deepest sense, through marriage. Once their sin was revealed, they didn't fight against it, try to hide it or point out the other sins of people around them. They sinned together and then welcomed conviction and accountability together. To right their mistakes, they responded with collective brokenness and repentance together.

When was the last time you participated in collective accountability and repentance? Have you ever participated in this type of accountability? I recall a time in my twenties when my church held a repentance and reconciliation service to foster stronger accountability within the church body. We prayed, cried, confessed and then we repented. Since that experience, I have returned to the practice many times. God convicts and transforms my life every time I return, restoring me and providing deep healing.

Can we try it today? Even though we are in individual spaces instead of a communal service, we can seek collective repentance. Individually, in your home, carve out time to pray and seek the Lord for whatever sins He would be calling you to repent and walk away from today. When we collectively seek accountability and repentance, God changes us and also our community because he changes our hearts. Our hearts, once again, break for what breaks His heart and our minds focus on the things of Christ instead of the things of this world.

Use Ezra's prayer of confession in Ezra 9 to guide you if this is a new practice. Be careful not to walk away from your convictions without initiating change. True repentance requires tangible brokenness and change and change is only accomplished through accountability. Commit to sharing your convictions with someone and asking for their help.
Let's strive to be a community that embraces and continually models accountability and repentance in our lives.
Pastor Kim Davis

paragraphs: To Do List

Are you a list maker? I'm a habitual list creator. If a task comes to mind, I add it to my “to do list”. As the day passes, it grows and may reproduce into more lists: groceries, errands, vacation plans or possibly, even, an expense budget. Perhaps I'm not the only one to admit to carrying a scrap of paper tucked in a pocket as a reminder. Often it's neatly scribed with bold checkmarks added upon successful completion giving me a sense of satisfaction! Smart phones can also organize information quickly into lists with the potential to set reminders. Entering prayer requests to a list on a phone may also be a practical way of reference and remembrance.

In the book of Nehemiah, chapter one expresses how God has put the desire into Nehemiah's heart to rebuild the walls of Jerusalem and its gates that had been destroyed by fire. As the King grants him leave as his cupbearer and also provides the materials to make the repairs, Nehemiah put his heart toward the work. In reading chapter three, we see that he begins to make a “list”. He has likely already considered the timeline and materials, but this account documents a different focus. He lists the repairs by the people of Israel as a record of their labour and commitment to rebuild the wall of Jerusalem. Nehemiah details the names, repairs, scope of work and in one verse: the attitude associated to the effort or lack thereof. “And next to them the Tekoires repaired, but their nobles would not stoop to serve their Lord.” (Nehemiah 3:5)

How many efforts fall to the wayside when the support of the people wanes? Nehemiah began with a burden for the restoration of the walls, but he couldn't complete the task without the efforts of everyone. After his assessment of the work, he needed the people to come together in unity for the restoration. God's leading of Nehemiah inspired the people of Israel to complete in unity the task before them. The restored wall brings security, beauty and faithfulness back again to Jerusalem.

If we as followers of Christ seek His purpose in unity, I'm confident that we will see a move of God in our city. “Behold, how good and pleasant it is when brothers dwell in unity.” (Psalm 133:1). Let's add “unity of the believers at WPA” to our prayer list and remember whom it is we  serve.
Ben Guse (Deacon)

paragraphs: The Call of Duty

Attacks by the enemy should not be new to Christians. Our enemy continues to use deception and deceiving schemes to try to dissuade God's people from doing what He has called them to do. The Apostle Paul warned us in Ephesian 6:11 to “Put on the full armour of God, so that you will be able to stand firm against the schemes of the devil”. As children of God, to accomplish His purpose for our lives, we must learn to resist the devil's schemes just as Nehemiah had to endure many attacks.

Following the threats from his enemies and the internal conflict between the wealthy and poor Jews, Nehemiah could see that the rebuilding of the walls of Jerusalem was almost done. Most of the work had been completed except for the doors in the gates, but the enemy had not given up. It was no longer a question of discouraging the builders. They recognized that it was now time to dispose of or dishonour Nehemiah once and for all. Sanballat, governor of Samaria, and Geshem, king of Kedar came together to plot to discredit and get rid of him (6:1-9) and to make him act in such a way as to reveal himself as a weakling who is fearful of his enemies (6:10-14).

After failing in four attempts, Sanballat increased the pressure with a fifth open unsealed letter containing a rumor accusing Nehemiah of plotting to rebel and become the king; a sneaky attempt to build up suspicion against Nehemiah. Each time Nehemiah replied by declaring “No such things as you say are being done, but you invent them in your own heart” (6:8). Through deception with intimidation and fear they continued to design an effort to bring Nehemiah to do foolish things to lessen his interest and influence. Thus, they invented a claim of having a word from God that had the guise of saving Nehemiah's life, but actually with the intention of destroying Nehemiah's life (6:13). Despite all the attacks, Nehemiah resolved to call on God in prayer to remember those prophets, who had all seemingly tried to make him afraid, and deal with them accordingly (6:14).

We must never be overwhelmed by the persistence to do anything sinful or foolish. When we are attacked or tempted, we must resist with godly purpose and resolve. Every temptation to draw us from duty should rather quicken us towards our call of duty. We must pray for God's wisdom to direct us when to remain silent or to reply to false accusations. We must respond with prayer, keeping on with the work that God has given us to do. Satan still uses all sorts of innocent-sounding appeals to lure believers into traps. We must be careful with claims from people, even believers, pointing us towards doing something that we know is wrong. We need to remember that just because we resisted the devil once, doesn't mean he is going to give up and leave us alone.

Despite the secret communication and the challenges to the building of the wall, it was remarkably completed in fifty-two days! As Christians we must endeavor, at whatever cost, to never decline our call of duty: to do good work despite our challenges.

paragraphs: They Lacked Nothing!

“Because of your great compassion you did not abandon them in the wilderness. By day the pillar of cloud did not fail to guide them on their path, nor the pillar of fire by night to shine on the way they were to take. You gave your good Spirit to instruct them. You did not withhold your manna from their mouths, and you gave them water for their thirst.  For forty years you sustained them in the wilderness; they lacked nothing, their clothes did not wear out nor did their feet become swollen.” (Nehemiah 9:19-21)

As we seek to fulfill God's great plans through our lives, it is important to note how God cares for us and why He does care. The passage above is the perfect summary of our God who supernaturally provides care to the souls and bodies of His people to keep them well-sustained in fulfilling His plan because of His great compassion.

When it comes to fulfilling God's plan for our lives, we often come with this sense of inadequacy and rightfully so! If we think that it is easy to fulfill God's plan without God's support, we are only fooling ourselves. Though it can feel nerve-wracking to accomplish God's plan for our lives, this feeling of “anxiousness” should not be seen immediately as a sign of direction away from God's plan, but rather a sign to prayerfully seek God's strength to fulfill His plans.

The passage above comes from the Israelites' confession to God of His loving character displayed through the history of their forefathers. It is a strong admission of His faithfulness towards them; to lead them into His plans even when their predecessors failed to live honourably before Him.

The great catch of this confession is found in the sentence “they lacked nothing.” Even though they failed to live to God's standards, His compassion for His own people was so great that it not only was sealed with a promise, but that He sustained them completely to fulfill that promise. He treated them well beyond what they deserved. They experienced His grace!

As you read this devotional today, be encouraged to know that despite all of our failures, God's compassion is undeservingly great over us and He will give you everything that you need to do His will; you shall lack nothing (Ps. 23:1) because He is rich in mercy and grace!
As we ponder on this amazing truth, this doesn't mean we excuse ourselves from living according to God's standards. As it says in verse 20, “You gave your good Spirit to instruct them.”

For those who believe in Jesus Christ, God's begotten Son and our Saviour, God the Father has given us the Holy Spirit, who is good and also raised Jesus Christ from the dead, to live in us and to instruct us on how to live honourably! He will help us fulfill God's plan.

Questions to ask ourselves today as we read this passage: Are we fulfilling God's will on our own strength or on His strength? Are we cherishing His great compassion over us; where despite our sinfulness, He still has given us everything we need to fulfill His plan? Are we listening to the Holy Spirit who instructs us and teaches us in the way we should go?
Pastor Joshua Mathew

paragraphs: In The Details

Did you feel like skipping over today's reading because you saw a list of names? You are not alone, many of us do that when we see these lists of names or genealogies. Nehemiah 12 begins with listing the priests and Levites. The Levites were being gathered for the dedication ceremony of the wall of Jerusalem. The Bible could have just said, “the Levites and priests,” but no. Instead they were each listed by name. We may think that reading them won't make a difference, they're sometimes hard to pronounce and we assume we don't get much out of reading them.

These lists support the Bible's historical accuracy and credibility, they confirm the existence of these people, they confirm prophecy and demonstrate just how much our God, our BIG GOD is concerned with the details. He is very attentive, detailed and meticulous. Each of these Levites and priests were chosen and formed to live out a specific purpose: designed by God, destined by God, to be priests, to be worshippers and to lead others in worship. Every single name represents a whole person, a whole life, a whole plan, a whole purpose, a person gifted by God and made in His image.

As they were dedicating the wall of Jerusalem, the Levites were, “sought out from where they lived and were brought to Jerusalem to celebrate joyfully the dedication with songs of thanksgiving and with the music of cymbals, harps and lyres.” (Neh 12:27). Just think about that; these people were each named in the Bible, they were sought out, they came here to Jerusalem for a purpose. The celebration of the dedication of the wall involved these hand-picked people. The ceremony was well ordered and each of them had a specific role to play. We all have a gift which assists in making the body of Christ complete.

You were created on purpose for a purpose. “Before I formed you in the womb I knew you, before you were born I set you apart; I appointed you as a prophet to the nations.” (Jer. 1:5) Don't ever lose your wonder of the meticulous nature of our God. It's something we know, but often we forget.

As we live day to day remember that God is a detail-oriented God. The hairs of your head are numbered. He cares about the little details that upset you or delight you, no matter how insignificant they seem. Be encouraged today to take some time to fixate on just how marvellous it is that He is so involved in every detail and has ordained every specific situation and opportunity that comes into your path. He formed you specifically to deal with that situation or take up that opportunity in your own unique way. May we never lose our wonder of Him.
Riana Jagessar (Deacon)
